body:
Am also getting this on xmonad (i.e. tiling wm w/o decorations).
```
os: NixOS, kernel 5.4.15, xmonad 0.15, xorg 1.20.5, amdgpu driver
```
Thank you for reporting this. It was fixed with 9372ba95faabd1bb45280d201d6ccdae77bf872e in #1620, which was included in the recent 3.3.2 release.
Thanks @elmindreda.  I can confirm that 9372ba9 works for me.
I'm on Arch Linux with X11 - using 3.3.2 and still have the same issue - same error with `glfwPollEvents()`. Any hint how to debug that it seems to crash deep inside of X11?
@seichter Have you checked the version string in case it's an older binary interfering somewhere?

Yes. It's same and I made sure its not interfering with the system installed GLFW. Basically I am rewriting one of my old 3D engines and use GLFW as input and window handler. Source in in-tree for the code, the library is built as subproject with CMake and linked statically. If I leave out `glfwPollEvents()` things work but obviously I have no input handling and the like.
@seichter I cannot reproduce this with 3.3.2. What window related hints do you set? Does the bundled GLFW test `windows` have the same issue on your machine?
I drilled it down to [this line](https://github.com/glfw/glfw/blob/0ac013381be83fcd6e53ea874f09b1895943bd9e/src/x11_window.c#L1561) but couldn't figure out what might caused it.

@seichter What window manager are you using?

It could happen if the window was reparented and the parent window destroyed before GLFW processed the configure event. I'll add an Xlib error handler grab around using the cached parent handle.

I'm on ArchLinux with latest Gnome/Mutter in a gnome-session - the problem appeared already with the old 3.34.x series. Both machines are using the proprietary NVidia driver (if enabled). One machine is using a patched gdm from AUR for optimus-manager and is usually running with the Intel driver - problem persists independently of driver.

```
$ pacman -Q mutter gnome-session gnome-shell
mutter 3.36.0-1
gnome-session 3.36.0-1
gnome-shell 1:3.36.0-3
```
@seichter Does this happen when you poll right after window creation or when you do something with the window via input or code or something else?

@elmindreda I was just digging a bit deeper in my code. The engine code was after window initialization and setting up callbacks hiding the window (with glfwHideWindow) and shortly before starting the update loop showing it again (with glfwShowWindow). If I disable this, the update loop works as expected. In glfw 3.2.1 there was no problem here.
@seichter Oh, that makes perfect sense. Thank you!
